intro: Wikstroemia vaccinium, commonly known as the Hawaiian sandalwood, is a small evergreen shrub native to the Hawaiian Islands. It belongs to the family Thymelaeaceae and is characterized by its narrow, leathery leaves and clusters of small, fragrant white flowers. The plant produces small, fleshy fruits that are often consumed by native birds and insects. It thrives in coastal and lowland habitats, often growing in well-drained soils. Due to its ecological importance and limited distribution, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
